image.altText: Generic image of a car parked on the side of the road

props.synopsis: Statistician Glen Thomas Heyen was charged with wilful and unlawful damage after a number of cars were allegedly keyed on a busy road.

title.children: Treasury bureaucrat faces court over allegations he keyed illegally-parked cars in Brisbane

image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An inquiry into government response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been announced, but state and territory local lockdowns and border closures are likely to avoid scrutiny.

title.children: Lockdowns and border closures omitted in scope of inquiry into government COVID-19 pandemic response

image.altText: The silhouette of a power station is seen against the sky in the early evening, with thick smoke billowing from three towers.

props.synopsis: There are growing safety concerns at Yallourn Power Station in Victoria, one of Australia's biggest coal-fired power plants. Experts say that could be bad news heading into a long, hot summer.

title.children: Dark clouds gather over one of Australia's biggest coal plants as El Niño heats the land

image.altText: A woman in silhouette stands in front of a rack of clothes.

props.synopsis: The 30-year-old is expected to face court today over what police allege are "serious and traumatic" crimes.

title.children: Queensland man accused of robbing two sex workers at gun and knifepoint in less than a day

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

props.synopsis: The country is transitioning through the largest building code changes in a decade. But what does this mean for home owners?

title.children: Building your dream home? Here's what you'll need to consider under new construction code changes

image.altText: A drone overhead shot of a dusty dig site

props.synopsis: You don't need to be a palaeontologist to dig up dinosaur bones. These volunteers are unearthing a 95-million-year-old sauropod skeleton near Winton, proving all you need is curiosity and a keen eye.

title.children: At this outback dig, volunteers with a lifelong passion for dinosaurs are 'finding new bones every day'

image.altText: A woman sits at a poker machine. Surrounding her are several large, bright and colourfully lit machines.

props.synopsis: A gambling reform advocate says she suspects people are gambling and trying to get in front of the curve when things are tough.

title.children: Queensland gambling losses climb beyond $5 billion a year

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN, Ukraine calls for stripping of Russia's veto power

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: Danushka Gunathilaka outside court

props.synopsis: In a closing address, Crown Prosecutor Gabrielle Steedman says the alleged victim's sexual episode with cricketer Danushka Gunathilaka "turned out very differently to what she expected or wanted".

title.children: Cricketer Danushka Gunathilaka pursued woman 'relentlessly' before alleged sexual assault, court told

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: A teenage boy and girl, dressed in colourful clothes, walk their bikes as they chat outside school.

props.synopsis: The British sex comedy has portrayed the teenage experience with nuance and humour. Here's everything you need to know before pressing play on the final season.

title.children: The final season of Sex Education has arrived. Here's everything you need to know before saying goodbye

image.altText: A Cambodian woman holds a sign reading "Pay your workers".

props.synopsis: The women making clothes and shoes for some of the world's biggest brands have seen their wages drop and are spiralling into debt, even as fashion companies see revenues rise, according to a new report.

title.children: They make clothes for the biggest sporting brands in the world. But these women are spiralling in debt distress

image.altText: a young woman sick with a cold sitting on a bed blowing her nose with a tissue

props.synopsis: Queensland's chief health officer says the public should be "alert but not alarmed", after a surge in Group A Streptococcus infections. Here's how to stay safe.

title.children: 'Rare' strep A infections have jumped in Queensland, with a childcare worker currently in hospital

image.altText: Jarome Luai sits on the ground

props.synopsis: Star five-eighth Jarome Luai has been cleared to return from a dislocated shoulder for Penrith's preliminary final against Melbourne.

title.children: Luai cleared to play for Panthers in prelim against Storm

image.altText: Senior man wearing a shirt receives an injection in his arm.

props.synopsis: If it has been six months or longer since you last had a COVID-19 infection or a vaccine dose, you might be eligible for a booster. Here's what you need to know before getting one.

title.children: A new COVID-19 virus has been detected onshore. So is it time to get a booster?

image.altText: Bomb remains in dirt next to small signs with skull and crossbones on them.

props.synopsis: In a letter to the US government, a UN torture expert says cluster munitions — which are prohibited by more than 100 countries — "indiscriminately and seriously injure civilians both at the time of use and in post-conflict" and should not be used.

title.children: US urged not to give Ukraine cluster munitions which could 'remain dangerous for decades'

image.altText: The six politicians stand in front of the US Capitol building.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: Julian Assange unites cross-party delegation in Washington to push for WikiLeaks founder's freedom

image.altText: Trees in Beerwah stand burnt and blacked from fire

props.synopsis: Queensland Ambulance Service supervisor Mitch Ware says paramedics are prepared for an "early taste" of El Niño.

title.children: Queensland on bushfire and heat alert with 'early taste' of El Niño

image.altText: Writers and supporters holding up signs such as "Writers Guild of America on Strike!" and "It didn't have to be this way"

props.synopsis: Writers and producers could soon reach an agreement to end the writers strike, according to sources, following a meeting with top Hollywood executives.

title.children: 'Positive sign': Hollywood writers talk with studios in hopes of ending strike

image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: A night vision image of a pet cat carrying native prey in it's mouth.

props.synopsis: An ecologist warns pet owners to keep predatory animals secure, after a cat is spotted on the Yorke Peninsula in South Australia posing a threat to recently reintroduced brush-tailed bettongs.

title.children: Pet cat caught on camera carrying native prey in national park home to precious endangered bettong colony

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: a man in an office with documents

props.synopsis: The ASX sheds 1 per cent in line with global markets after the US central bank stiffens its hawkish stance, while former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX sheds 1pc, former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US interest rates unchanged

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Back again with more on that inquiry: Danielle Jaeger is one of 600 consumers who wrote submissions to the ACTU inquiry into unfair pricing. She'll be appearing before Professor Fels later today. Ms Jaeger has seen all her bills increase this year, including a 40 per cent increase on her home insurance, despite not making a claim. " There's been no reason or justification around the bill hike which for me has been really distressing," she told my colleague Emily Stewart. "I've noticed a significant cost of living increasing over the last 12 months. "What's been really alarming for me across the board is that it's affected in terms of bills or whether it's utility costs, phone services, internet - my usage has not increased, it's actually decreased because it's something that I'm particularly honing in on to reduce any costs and to be as savvy as possible." While Ms Jaeger already works full time as a nurse, she is now looking at getting a second job to make ends meet. "It's really overwhelming and a really difficult position to be in because I never thought I'd be considering whether I pay for a family member's medication or whether we can go to the doctor." Emily will be wrapping up today's proceedings in the inquiry for ABC News tonight as well as The Business - so tune in for that coverage this evening or on iView .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumers consider taking on extra work to make ends meet

children.content: Back again with more on that inquiry:
Danielle Jaeger
is one of
consumers who wrote submissions to the ACTU inquiry into unfair pricing.
She'll be appearing before Professor Fels later today.
Ms Jaeger has seen all her bills increase this year, including a
40 per cent increase
on her
home insurance
, despite not making a claim.
There's been no reason or justification around the bill hike
which for me has been really distressing," she told my colleague Emily Stewart.
"I've noticed a significant cost of living increasing over the last 12 months.

"What's been really alarming for me across the board is that it's affected in terms of bills or whether it's utility costs, phone services, internet - my usage has not increased, it's actually decreased because it's something that I'm particularly honing in on to reduce any costs and to be as savvy as possible."
While Ms Jaeger already works full time as a nurse, she is now
looking at getting a second job
to make ends meet.
"It's really overwhelming and a really difficult position to be in because I never thought I'd be considering whether I pay for a family member's medication or whether we can go to the doctor."
Emily will be wrapping up today's proceedings in the inquiry for
ABC News tonight
as well as
The Business
- so tune in for that coverage this evening or on
iView

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ's head of foreign exchange research Mahjabeen Zaman has been speaking to my colleague Sue Lannin about the US Federal Reserve. It kept official interest rates on hold, at their highest level in more than two decades, last night. But it indicated it may raise its benchmark interest rate one more time this year to get inflation down to its target of two per cent. Ms Zaman told business reporter Sue the Fed needs to do more to lower the cost of living. You can watch their interview on ABC iView.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another rate rise likely in the US

featuredLink.title: ABC News Stories: US Federal Reserve indicates further rate hikes

children.content: ANZ's head of foreign exchange research Mahjabeen Zaman
has been speaking to my colleague
Sue Lannin
about the US Federal Reserve.
It kept official interest rates on hold, at their highest level in more than two decades, last night.
But it indicated it
may raise its benchmark interest rate one more time this year
to get inflation down to its target of two per cent.
Ms Zaman told business reporter Sue the Fed needs to do more to lower the cost of living.
You can watch their interview on ABC iView.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: All sectors on the ASX are in the red today. The top 200 index has extended its losses this afternoon, now down about 1.3 per cent as I write this at 2.08pm AEST. Here's a snapshot of how the sectors are going. But not all stocks are in the red. Here are the top performers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: I see red, I see red, I see red

children.content: All sectors on the ASX are in the red today.
The top 200 index has extended its losses this afternoon, now down about 1.3 per cent as I write this at 2.08pm AEST.
Here's a snapshot of how the sectors are going.
(Refinitive)
But not all stocks are in the red.
Here are the top performers.

image.altText: A composite image of Peter Hudson on the left and Magenta Marshall on the right.

props.synopsis: The WA Liberal Party's candidate in the Rockingham by-election apologises for asking a constituent to question his opponent whether she would resign from parliament if she fell pregnant.

title.children: Scheme to ask by-election rival about her pregnancy plans ends in 'regret' from Liberal candidate

image.altText: Kylie Minogue wearing a red dress and long red gloves, looking away from the camera with hand on hip and longish blonde hair

props.synopsis: Australia's pop princess Kylie Minogue has been nominated for four ARIAs. If she wins at least one, it will be her first ARIA in more than two decades.

title.children: If Kylie Minogue wins a 2023 ARIA, it will be her first in more than 20 years

image.altText: Wind turbines are set to dot the landscape in Victoria's west

props.synopsis: Some experts are warning Australia's ambitions to have zero carbon emissions by 2050 need to be scaled up dramatically.

title.children: Reaching net zero by 2035 would take a 'gargantuan' effort. But these experts say our current 2050 target is just too far away

image.altText: A three-panel image showing a young, ginger-haired woman, a dark-haired man and a dark-haired woman.

props.synopsis: Ballarat is witnessing anti-trans demonstrations on a weekly basis but trans supporters say the protesters do not represent the regional city.

title.children: Ballarat attracts weekly anti-trans demonstrations, but the community fights back

image.altText: Reserve Bank Governor Ian Macfarlane makes a point

props.synopsis: The proposed move to establish a separate body within the Reserve Bank to make interest rates decisions in future, was "very bad policy" and "a leap of faith" which would undermine the authority of the governor, according to former governor Ian Macfarlane.

title.children: 'Very bad policy': Former RBA governor calls for discussions around bank's changes

image.altText: Man in a suit stands for his bail hearing in front of a crowd of photograpers.

props.synopsis: Oscar Pistorius was eligible for parole in March and the double-amputee Olympic runner may have been wrongly denied early release from prison because of an error.

title.children: Oscar Pistorius may have been wrongly denied parole over error

image.altText: A Pizza Hut sign.

props.synopsis: Pizza Hut Australia says the data breach only impacted the Australian market and does not affect Pizza Hut's operations in any other country.

title.children: Nearly 200k Pizza Hut customers affected by cyber hack
